newsitem.title: JAPAN: Crudes rise in Asia, Umm Shaif, Dubai trade higher.
newsitem.headline: Crudes rise in Asia, Umm Shaif, Dubai trade higher.

text.p: Crude prices were firmer in Asia on Friday, with Abu Dhabi Umm Shaif and Dubai crude trading at firmer spot market premiums, traders said.
Umm Shaif switched hands between majors at ADNOC plus 14 cents, up sharply from the last deal at plus one cent.

Traders said values were pushed up because supplies are scarce compared to usual months due to a turnaround at the Umm Shaif field. They said supplies of Lower Zakum were also low, because of field maintenance.
Only one cargo of Lower Zakum remains in the market, traders said.

May Dubai switched hands at front-month quotes plus 33/34 cents, up from the last deal levels of plus 28.5 cents, traders said. They said the cargo may have a specific loading date, which would explain the higher price.
In other Abu Dhabi grades, Murban traded twice at ADNOC flat on Wednesday, unchanged from the last deals, once between majors and a second time from a major to Kenya, traders said.
Market rumours held of a U.S. major planning to ship 900,000 barrels of Nigerian Pennington to Asia, possibly Japan.
Traders said the purchase would be economical given current Brent/Dubai spreads and weak Dated Brent prices.
The U.S. major is believed to have plans to replace Abu Dhabi grades for Nigerian crudes, traders said.

In paper spreads, May Brent/Dubai was assessed at around $1.50/1.60, unchanged from overnight U.S. levels. May/June Dubai was assessed at about 22 cents, after trading at 20 cents on Thursday. May Cash Brent was assessed at $20.30/20.40, unchanged from midday Asian levels.
Traders said they expected end-users, who have been relatively relaxed this week, to become more active next week as refining programmes become clear.
